sentence:
Open in a new tabProposed solution
Considering the existing distribution of human resources, infrastructure, and planned patient load at each level of care, we propose a new model of Integrated care framework called the “Indian Model of Integrated Healthcare (IMIH).” The model has been planned at three levels of integration: Macro, Meso, and Micro levels Integration using the existing HDS as follows:


AMacro level of integration:
The Macro Level of Integration will help in load-balancing by diverting patients in a coordinated manner through a gateway between 3 tiers of HDS using the Central Gateway Control Room (CGCR) within the states, which can be scaled up in later stages, to include the apex centres (Fig. 1).
Each SdC will be a replica of the other, having identical health resources (Fig. 2).
Within each spoke the allocation of patients to each capsule will be done per the bucket overflow model (Fig. 3).

CMicro level of integration
Each SdC constitutes five major components, i.e., Out Patient Department (OPD), Inpatient Patient Department, Emergency, Minor Operation Theater, and ancillary and auxiliary services (Fig. 5).

Functioning of the OPDs will be based on a proposed Triple-layered Concentric Circle Out Patient Department (TLCCO) design, planned to have First, ancillary and auxiliary services in the outer ring, Second, screening OPD in the middle ring, and Third, Referral and Cross Referral cases in the third innermost ring (Fig. 6).
TDO will prevent the intermixing of patients and provide a unidirectional flow of patients (Fig. 6).

Proposed solution
Considering the existing distribution of human resources, infrastructure, and planned patient load at each level of care, we propose a new model of Integrated care framework called the “Indian Model of Integrated Healthcare (IMIH).” The model has been planned at three levels of integration: Macro, Meso, and Micro levels Integration using the existing HDS as follows:


AMacro level of integration:
The Macro Level of Integration will help in load-balancing by diverting patients in a coordinated manner through a gateway between 3 tiers of HDS using the Central Gateway Control Room (CGCR) within the states, which can be scaled up in later stages, to include the apex centres (Fig. 1).
Each SdC will be a replica of the other, having identical health resources (Fig. 2).
Within each spoke the allocation of patients to each capsule will be done per the bucket overflow model (Fig. 3).

CMicro level of integration
Each SdC constitutes five major components, i.e., Out Patient Department (OPD), Inpatient Patient Department, Emergency, Minor Operation Theater, and ancillary and auxiliary services (Fig. 5).

Functioning of the OPDs will be based on a proposed Triple-layered Concentric Circle Out Patient Department (TLCCO) design, planned to have First, ancillary and auxiliary services in the outer ring, Second, screening OPD in the middle ring, and Third, Referral and Cross Referral cases in the third innermost ring (Fig. 6).
TDO will prevent the intermixing of patients and provide a unidirectional flow of patients (Fig. 6).

Macro level of integration:
The Macro Level of Integration will help in load-balancing by diverting patients in a coordinated manner through a gateway between 3 tiers of HDS using the Central Gateway Control Room (CGCR) within the states, which can be scaled up in later stages, to include the apex centres (Fig. 1).

Each SdC will be a replica of the other, having identical health resources (Fig. 2).
Within each spoke the allocation of patients to each capsule will be done per the bucket overflow model (Fig. 3).

Micro level of integration
Each SdC constitutes five major components, i.e., Out Patient Department (OPD), Inpatient Patient Department, Emergency, Minor Operation Theater, and ancillary and auxiliary services (Fig. 5).

Functioning of the OPDs will be based on a proposed Triple-layered Concentric Circle Out Patient Department (TLCCO) design, planned to have First, ancillary and auxiliary services in the outer ring, Second, screening OPD in the middle ring, and Third, Referral and Cross Referral cases in the third innermost ring (Fig. 6).
TDO will prevent the intermixing of patients and provide a unidirectional flow of patients (Fig. 6).
